item.title: Sainsbury's Raises Full-Year Guidance
item.description: Sainsbury’s lifted its guidance for fiscal 2024 on volume strength as it posted sales growth driven by groceries for the first half of the year.

item.title: Dollar's Future Gains Might Be More Modest Than Expected
item.description: The window for dollar strength remains open but the lack of its appreciation in October as U.S. bond yields surged increases the risks of the scale of dollar gains being more modest than expected by MUFG.

item.title: Shell Announces $3.5 Billion Buyback
item.description: Shell launched a $3.5 billion share buyback program after third-quarter earnings rose on higher refining margins, oil prices and sales, but slightly missed market expectations.

item.title: Malaysia Central Bank Keeps Policy Rate Unchanged
item.description: Bank Negara Malaysia said the country’s growth outlook faces risks such as weak external demand and protracted declines in commodities production.

item.title: Novo Nordisk Continues to Limit Wegovy Supplies
item.description: Novo Nordisk is gradually expanding supply capacity for its blockbuster weight-loss drug, but said it will continue to limit supply of lower-strength doses of the Wegovy medicine in the U.S. as it seeks to safeguard supplies.

item.title: Lufthansa Beats Views, Sees Continued Strong Demand
item.description: Lufthansa said it expected capacity in the current quarter to reach around 91% of 2019 levels and confirmed its adjusted EBIT forecast for the year after it reported third-quarter earnings ahead of consensus.

item.title: Nikkei Rises 1.1%, Led by Electronics Stocks
item.description: Japanese stocks ended higher, led by gains in electronics stocks, as concerns eased about borrowing costs following the Fed’s pause on rate increases.

item.title: Foreign Nationals Start to Leave Gaza at Egyptian Border
item.description: More than 400 people, including wounded Palestinians and some Americans, crossed into Egypt from the Rafah border, Egyptian and U.S. officials say.

item.title: Glynn's Take: RBA Policy Decision Seems Too Tough to Call With Cautious Bullock at the Helm
item.description: The Australian central bank is likely still weighing whether the buildup in price pressures will force it to revise its expectation that inflation will return to the desired target.

item.title: Santos's Barossa Gas Pipeline Delayed by Australian Court
item.description: The energy explorer’s attempt to lay a pipeline through a gas field off Australia’s north coast has been held up after a court granted an interim injunction delaying the start of the project.

item.title: How Russia Is Restructuring Wagner Group's Africa Operations
item.description: After the death of Wagner leader Yevgeny Prigozhin, the Kremlin is putting a new power structure in place that will take over the group’s sprawling operations in Africa, which have advanced Russian influence on the continent for almost a decade.

item.title: Shein Turns to Western Executives to Become Even More Global
item.description: Entangled in geopolitical friction, the China-founded e-commerce powerhouse taps American executive Frances Townsend.

item.title: In West Bank, Israeli Settlers Step Up Attacks Against Palestinians
item.description: A series of shootings that left six dead and two communities divided is part of a spasm of violence.

item.title: Why Jamie Dimon Changed His Mind on Europe
item.description: After shunning overseas retail banking, JPMorgan is expanding in the U.K. and preparing to launch in other European countries.

item.title: Italy's Rumbling Supervolcano Has Half a Million Residents on Edge
item.description: Campi Flegrei, not far from ill-fated Pompeii, has had 2,500 earthquakes in the past three months, a sign of volcanic activity deep underground.

item.title: Toyota gave most of its U.S. auto-factory workers a 9% pay bump and shortened the time it takes to reach maximum pay, a sign that gains the UAW made in Detroit are rippling through the auto industry.
item.description: Toyota gave most of its U.S. auto-factory workers a 9% pay bump and shortened the time it takes to reach maximum pay, a sign that gains the UAW made in Detroit are rippling through the auto industry.

item.title: Died: Bob Knight, 83, fiery college basketball coach.
item.description: Died: Bob Knight, 83, fiery college basketball coach.

item.title: U.S. stocks rose after the Fed extended its rate-rise pause, with the S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow gaining 1.1%, 1.6% and 0.7%, respectively, while Treasury yields fell.
item.description: U.S. stocks rose after the Fed extended its rate-rise pause, with the S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow gaining 1.1%, 1.6% and 0.7%, respectively, while Treasury yields fell.

item.title: Disney said it expects to pay Comcast's NBCUniversal at least $8.61 billion for its stake in Hulu, as the companies continue complex negotiations over the future of the streaming-video service.
item.description: Disney said it expects to pay Comcast’s NBCUniversal at least $8.61 billion for its stake in Hulu, as the companies continue complex negotiations over the future of the streaming-video service.

item.title: Airstrikes on a densely populated neighborhood in Gaza this week show that Israel is waging a broader and more ferocious war against Hamas, an approach that aims to destroy the Palestinian militant group but has sparked an international backlash.
item.description: Airstrikes on a densely populated neighborhood in Gaza this week show that Israel is waging a broader and more ferocious war against Hamas, an approach that aims to destroy the Palestinian militant group but has sparked an international backlash.
